snippet: Eager to tap China’s movie market, Hollywood studios try to win censors’ approval — taking on Chinese partners, tweaking story lines and, when filming in China, inviting bureaucrats to the set.
abstract: Lure of access to China’s fast-growing film market is entangling American studios and filmmakers with state censors in country where American notions of free expression simply do not apply; studios have discovered that navigating murky, often shifting terrain of censorship is a critical part of the process in seeking international box-office revenue, with billions of dollars riding on whether they get it right

byline.original: By MICHAEL CIEPLY and BROOKS BARNES

lead_paragraph: Eager to tap China’s movie market, Hollywood studios try to win censors’ approval — taking on Chinese partners, tweaking story lines and, when filming in China, inviting bureaucrats to the set.

headline.seo: In Hollywood Movies for China, Bureaucrats Want a Say
headline.main: To Get Movies Into China, Hollywood Gives Censors a Preview
headline.print_headline: To Get Movies Into China, Hollywood Gives Censors a Preview
